instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi!


I have this PCB without traces of humidity but it does't turn on:

- <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0V (not short)

Greetings and thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks for replying [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] .

No, I don't have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> too?
Confirm that.

Check <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Be sure to use original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yes,  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 0.00V. 

<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.30V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Now check <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and all PCH's (DC) RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.23V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0.00V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 3.07V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.25V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3_PCH</SIGNAL> = 3.34V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0.00V"
What about <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?

Check <RESISTOR>R5092</RESISTOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5092</RESISTOR>:
- pin 1: 3.40V
- pin 2: 3.43V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"What about <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?"
It is on <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR>.

I said to check <RESISTOR>R5092</RESISTOR> for other reason; it controls <SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0.055V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"It is on <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR>."
You've checked voltage on both pins of <RESISTOR>R5092</RESISTOR> before; why not this time?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR>:
- pin 1: 3.43V
- pin 2: 0.055V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Remove resistor and check its ohm value.
If <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (L7260) is present, then pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR> MUST go high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR>= 99.8K ohms.

Yes, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present on L7260.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Try cutting off the trace to <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>, pin 20.
Choose a point where you can recover the trace later.

You can also try changing <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> instead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have cut the trace, I have changed <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and still the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes high, once trace is cutted off?
<RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR> must be kept in place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR>:
- pin 1: 3.43V
- pin 2: 0.055V 

<RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR> is in place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
SMC problem; it pulls down the signal.
Try reballing it first.
May need to change it.
